awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Potential Vorticity Mixing Experiments on COMPASS Plasma Device
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support an experimental plasma-based study of how large-scale flows may emerge from small-scale turbulence in rotating systems.  The behavior of fluid-like media in rotating stars and gas giant planets, in the oceans and molten cores of rotating Earth-like planets, and in plasmas with strong magnetic fields is profoundly affected by the forces associated with the overall rotation on the medium itself.  These forces lead to the emergence of well ordered, slowly varying sheared flows. Theory predicts that all such systems share the same underlying origin of the sheared flows via a quantity known as the potential vorticity. In a rotating fluid, for example in geophysical, planetary and stellar systems, the potential vorticity is given by a combination of the local fluid vorticity and the planetary rotation itself.  The experimental study supported by this award will make the first-ever attempt to directly test the role that potential vorticity plays in the formation of sheared flows in turbulent magnetized plasmas and will have broader implications for future development of fusion energy sources.  The experiment will be performed on the COMPASS plasma device in the Czech Republic, and the subsequent data analysis will be carried out by upper-division undergraduate students.

This project will provide an experimental test of the theoretical prediction that turbulence-generated shear flows appear in magnetized toroidal plasmas due to the effects of a strong Lorentz force, and as such follow similar underlying nonlinear dynamics to that responsible for shear flow formation found in the atmospheres of planets and stars due to the effects of the Coriolis force.  Should this experiment demonstrate that this is the case, it would provide a strong link between these two seemingly disparate physical systems. Should the result show that the prediction is in fact incorrect, it would then force a fundamental rethinking of the theory. In either case, the outcome will impact our understanding of self-organization processes in turbulent fluid and plasma systems.  This award is supported by the Division of Physics with additional support from the Office of Multidisciplinary Activities and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Overview

The dynamical behavior of fluid-like media in rotating stars and gas giant planets, in the atmospheres and oceans and molten cores of rotating Earth-like planets, and in strongly magnetized plasmas is profoundly affected by the effects of a sufficiently strong Coriolis force (in the case of stars and planets) or a strong Lorentz force (in the case of magnetized plasmas).   These forces lead to the emergence of well ordered, slowly varying (or mean) counter-streaming flows that move in the east-west direction (in the case of a rotating system) or within magnetic flux surfaces (in the magnetized plasma case).  Theory[1] predicts that these phenomena share an underlying dynamical origin via a quantity known as the potential vorticity.  In a rotating fluid (e.g. for geophysical, planetary and stellar systems) the potential vorticity, q, is given by the sum of the component of the local fluid vorticity that is parallel to the axis of rotation and the planetary rotation itself.  In a magnetized plasma, the potential vorticity is related to a linear sum of the normalized density fluctuations, which can be measured with a simple single-tip Langmuir probe, and the plasma fluid vorticity, which is given by the Laplacian of the plasma potential fluctuations.

 This proposal supported an experiment on the COMPASS device to make the first-ever attempt to directly test the roll that potential vorticity mixing plays in the formation of sheared ExB flows in a turbulent magnetically confined plasmas.  We designed, fabricated, installed and operated a unique multipoint diagnostic that aimed to provide a dataset that tests the theoretical role of potential vorticity in the spontaneous formation and amplification of sheared flows within a magnetically confined plasma.   

Preliminary Results

This apparatus was used in summer 2020 to make a first attempt at these potential vorticity measurements.  A series of ohmically heated tokamak discharges were created, and the probe assembly was rapidly inserted into steady-state plasmas, and the density fluctuations and potential fluctuations were recorded.  Since the potential vorticity hypothesis being tested here requires, at a bare minimum, a clear statistically significant correlation and coherence between density fluctuations and vorticity fluctuations, we carried out several straightforward analysese of the data.  First, we approximate the Laplacian of the potential fluctuations with a finite-difference performed from the ball-pen probe array.  The plasma fluid vorticity, q, was then computed from the data We also computed a number of standard quantities for stochastic signals, including the cross-coherency between the density and potential fluctuations.Finally, from the time-averaged ball-point pen potential we computed the time-averaged radial electric field.

This analysis showed thatthere is a finite and measurable coherence between the density fluctuations and fluid vorticity in the open-field line region (where R-RVSL>0) and closed field line region (where R-RVSL<0).   Furthermore there is a clear change in sign of the cross-phase These changes are also closely linked to the spatial structure of the time-averaged radial electric field.  Moreover, an analysis of all of the useful plasma discharges tracked the position of the density-vorticity cross-coherence and the position of the ExB shear layer, as well as the width of the finite cross-coherence region and the width of the ExB shear layer.  Figure 3 below shows the results, which clearly indicate a link between the ExB shear layer and these statistical quantities.  All of these results were presented as a poster [2]at the APS DPP 2020 virtual meeting.

Status and Outlook

 After these findings we began to dive deeper in the data.  When we did that we found several internal discrepancies in the results that cast doubt on the validity of our inferred vorticity.  We suspect that these are caused by misalignment between the total magnetic field in the plasma (which contains an important contribution generated by the toroidal plasma current itself and thus is difficulty to precisely control).   Unfortunately the COMPASS device has now been decommissioned and a new confinement device is under construction at IPP Prague.  Resolution of these discrepancies requires additional experiments which are not possible right now.  Thus any further progress on this physics topic will have to wait until the device is back in operation. 

The experiment also suggests to the PI that this physics question of the role of potential vorticity in plasma shear layer formation could perhaps be better studied in a laboratory-scale experiment that uses the probe array here, that is ball-point pen probe concept.  The PI is now considering this possibility and may pursue this on one of the laboratory scale plasma devices at UC San Diego using separate DOE funding.


[1] Pedlosky, J., Geophysical fluid dynamics, Springer, NY, NY 1987.

[2] Anaheed Najmzadeh, et al.: Turbulent density, Reynold’s stress, and vorticity measurements in the COMPASS tokamak edge plasma APS DPP Meeting, 10 Nov 2020.
